ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about a wide variety of topics involved with critical theory and art, and from the lectures, I also gained a lot of insight about the other ideas surrounding core topics and how they relate to each other. This course taught me to write experimentally, be more confident in my intuition and the seemingly random connections I make between topics, and actually helped me decide my major. Love this class!

You'll learn how artists use long made up words and high floating concepts to make themselves feel self important about their work changing the world and being important when in a lot of cases, it's just really inaccessible and pretentious and no one really cares. There's a lot of intellectual name dropping going on here.
I was exposed to new artists and movements.
I particularly enjoyed the research project and final paper.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only way to improve this course is to cancel it forever and never run it again. By far the worst class I've taken at Yale. The readings were fine sometimes, and I've engaged with a lot of them in previous courses, but there was a lot of assumed knowledge and references to things that made things difficult to keep up with sometimes because there are no prerequisites for this class and there was such a wide breadth of stuff going on in this class and it's just overwhelming to deal with not knowing everything about everything and having that stuff come up all the time. Seriously, we had a lesson on speech acts and linguistics (for what reason, I cannot tell you) and I actually took a linguistics class on Pragmatics and I still didn't understand what was going on.
The guest lectures were amazing! The readings were also generally interesting, though some of the readings could be very dense, and the terminology can also be difficult to follow.

I think that Critical Theory is important because people need to be more aware about their society. But does it necessarily need to take on a Marxist/anticapitalist/socialist theme? (This is more an issue with the direction the field itself is heading) Maybe some of the issues that we face in our time like poverty etc are not necessarily the result of capitalism itself but could be the result of a capitalist system being degraded with extra loopholes and features? Once we were just chatting in the zoom room and high insurance premiums were brought up. I think this was a good example of what I am trying to describe. Some things were introduced to the capitalist system later on to make it more oppressive. Acts of corruption, but not inherently capitalist. Real critical analysis of a society could bring in multiple viewpoints. And there are also times we can be more critical of things that are commonly accepted. I keep on hearing about the exalted status of Black Lives Matter. Yes the statement itself is very true. But some believe that the organization is merely another front by the wealthy to 'fleece' African Americans of their money. This would be an interesting take.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since most art classes did not have in person meetings and space was not an issue this year, there was no reason for this class to be at 7pm on a Wednesday.
Taking short breaks during class (since it was almost two hours straight) was helpful!
I had no issues. Everything succeeded.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This is one of my favorite classes that I've taken here. I'm an art major, and I learned a lot in this class! Steiner is fantastic, the readings are well-chosen and eclectic (topics range from images and surveillance, to archives of Chicano vernacular photography, to the memory of plants, to poetry as a necessity and photography as death, to gift economies). I found myself looking forward to the readings every week, and annotated mine extensively.

Absolutely not, unless you like stringing together meaningless sequences of abstract nouns and esoteric terms and pretending like they have meaning, because then maybe you'll be one of the favorites. Otherwise this class is horrible and a waste of time. If you need to take it for a requirement, take Junior Seminar and not this class. If you're interested in the readings, just do them on your own. It's not worth the effort.
No, this is a terrible course.

Yes, but the amount you get out of this course is the amount you put in. Particularly for the final paper, I got a lot out of it, but also spent a lot of time researching and reading before narrowing down my ideas.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Sharing of video & audio links, weekly homework readings, in-class final project presentations, etc.
